docTitle.emphasis: A new Jurassic scansoriopterygid and the loss of membranous wings in theropod dinosaurs

subSection.paragraph:
Min Wang
1 , 2
* , Jingmai K. O’Connor
1 , 2
, Xing Xu
1 , 2
& Zhonghe Zhou
1 , 2

paragraph.emphasis: Powered flight evolved independently in vertebrates in the pterosaurs, birds and bats, each of which has a different configuration of the bony elements and epidermal structures that form the wings

1 , 2
. Whereas the early fossil records of pterosaurs and bats are sparse, mounting evidence (primarily from China) of feathered non-avian dinosaurs and stemward avians that derive primarily from the Middle–Upper Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous periods has enabled the slow piecing together of the origins of avian flight

3 , 4
. These fossils demonstrate that, close to the origin of flight, dinosaurs closely related to birds were experimenting with a diversity of wing structures

3 , 5
. One of the most surprising of these is that of the scansoriopterygid (Theropoda, Maniraptora) Yi qi , which has membranous wings—a flight apparatus that was previously unknown among theropods but that is used by both the pterosaur and bat lineages

6
. This observation was not universally accepted

7
. Here we describe a newly identified scansoriopterygid—which we name
Ambopteryx longibrachium
, gen. et sp. nov. —from the Upper Jurassic period. This specimen provides support for the widespread existence of membranous wings and the styliform element in the Scansoriopterygidae , as well as evidence for the diet of this enigmatic theropod clade. Our analyses show that marked changes in wing architecture evolved near the split between the Scansoriopterygidae and the avian lineage, as the two clades travelled along very different paths to becoming volant. The membranous wings supported by elongate forelimbs that are present in scansoriopterygids probably represent a short-lived experimentation with volant behaviour, and feathered wings were ultimately favoured during the later evolution of Paraves.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. ‘
Ambo
’, both (Latin); ‘ pteryx ’, wing (Latin), referring to the pterosaur-like wing that is present in this non-avian dinosaur; ‘
longibrachium
’ refers to the elongate forelimb ( brachium , upper arm (Latin)).

materialsCitation.paragraph:
Holotype .
Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology ( IVPP )
V24192
, an articulated and nearly complete skeleton with associated soft tissue preserved on a slab and counter slab ( Fig. 1 , Extended Data Fig. 1 ).

Locality and horizon. Near Wubaiding Village, Reshuitang Town, Lingyuan City, Liaoning Province , China ; early Upper Jurassic , stratigraphic equivalent of the Haifanggou Formation , Yanliao Biota ( Oxfordian stage, 163 million years ago (Ma)
8 , 9
; see Methods for the provenance of the holotype specimen).

subSubSection.paragraph:
IVPP V24192 is interpreted as a subadult or adult on the basis of the fusion of the pygostyle, and the absence of striations or pits to indicate periosteal ossification was incomplete. Osteohistological examination was attempted but no information could be extracted, owing to poor preservation and diagenetic alteration (Extended Data Fig. 2a, b ). IVPP V24192 is estimated to be 32 cm in body length and to have had a body mass approximately 306 g, using an empirical equation based on femur circumference
10
(see Methods).

The skull is anteroposteriorly short and dorsoventrally high (Extended Data Fig. 1c ), similar to other scansoriopterygids
6
. The neck is complete and consists of eight-to-ten articulated cervicals (axis and atlas included) ( Fig. 2a ). As in some oviraptorosaurs and therizinosaurs
11
—but unlike most other non-avian pennaraptorans
12
— the tail is short and ends in a pygostyle.In contrast to most other non-avian theropods
13
and stemward avians
12
, the free caudals lack a transition point.

The forelimb is gracile and markedly elongate ( Fig. 2c , Extended Data Fig. 3c ), with an intermembral index ((humerus + ulna)/ (femur + tibia)) of about 1.3, which surpasses that of other scansoriopterygids, as well as most non-avian theropods and stem avians (Supplementary Tables 1–3). The proximal margin of the humerus is strongly convex, whereas in Yi it is relatively flat. The straight ulna is shorter than the humerus and is nearly twice the transverse width of the radius, which is in stark contrast to the subtle difference between the ulna and the radius that is present in other scansoriopterygids
6 , 14 , 15
and many non-avian theropods
16
. An elongate bone is preserved that extends from the distal end of the left ulna; this bone is morphologically identical to the anomalous structure reported in Yi 6 , being rod-like, slightly curved and tapered distally (Extended Data Fig. 4 ). No comparable structure has hitherto been found in other dinosaurs
6
. We consider this bone homologous to that of Yi , and hereafter use the same terminology in referring to this bone as the styliform element
6
. The styliform element is shorter than the humerus in Ambopteryx , which is not the case in Yi . The hand morphology is characteristic of scansoriopterygids in that it shows a metacarpal III that is longer than metacarpal II, and an elongate digit III that is substantially longer than digit II
6 , 14
( Fig. 2c ). The manual phalangeal formula is 2-3-4. Phalanx I-1 terminates level with the distal end of metacarpal II, whereas in Yi and
Epidendrosaurus
this phalanx extends further distally (Extended Data Fig. 5 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
The postacetabular process of the ilium is dorsoventrally narrow (less than one-third of the height of the preacetabular process) and strap-like in lateral view (Extended Data Fig. 3b, d ), which contrasts with both the triangular form as in some oviraptorosaurs and troodontids
17 , 18
and the ventrally curved condition as in dromaeosaurids and stem avians
19
. As in Yi , the tibia is shorter than the humerus; the opposite is true in other non-avian pennaraptorans (Supplementary Table 3). Ambopteryx preserves approximately 20 stones and unidentified bony fragments just anterior to the pelvis and ventral to the vertebral column, which are interpreted as gastroliths and ingested remains, respectively ( Fig. 1 , Extended Data Fig. 1d ). The diet of scansoriopterygids has been unknown; the gastroliths and possible stomach contents preserved in Ambopteryx provide the some direct clues from which we can draw dietary inferences. The small number of gastroliths in Ambopteryx suggests that this taxon may not have been herbivorous—this also finds some support in the stomach contents, which appear to contain bone. Considering the unusual dental morphology of the scansoriopterygid clade, we suggest this group may have been omnivorous.

Feathers are densely preserved around the head, neck and the shoulder regions ( Fig. 1 , Extended Data Fig. 1 ). The matrix that surrounds the left hand, right forelimb and abdomen is coated in a brownish continuous layer that bears ripple-like striations ( Fig. 2c ), which is reminiscent of the membranous tissues reported in Yi 6 . Scanning electron microscopy reveals densely packed microscopic elliptic moulds within the neck feathers and membranous tissues (Extended Data Fig. 6 ). Following recent studies
20
, these moulds are interpreted as being produced by eumelanosomes (see Supplementary Information for additional description and discussion of diet).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Our phylogenetic analysis recovered Ambopteryx as the sister taxon to Yi within the clade Scansoriopterygidae ( Fig. 3a , Extended Data Fig. 7 ). The nearly complete postcranial skeleton of Ambopteryx provides a great deal of important morphological and ecological information that is not accessible from previously known scansoriopterygid specimens. The fused pygostyle in Ambopteryx adds to the known distribution of this feature among non-avian dinosaurs. The abbreviated tail and elongate forelimbs in scansoriopterygids—which evolved in parallel similar morphologies in Aves—would have increased stability during possible volant behaviour by shifting the centre of weight more anteriorly, closer to the centre of lift
7
.

The presence of a styliform element in Ambopteryx lends further credibility to previous interpretations of this structure in Yi 6 and confirms that this element is a genuine feature. Comparable elements (whether homologous or not) are otherwise unknown among dinosaurs
6
, but have evolved independently in some other tetrapod lineages that are adapted for volant behaviour
21 , 22
. Where the styliform element is present in extant vertebrates, it supports an expanded patagium and thus increases the viable area of the aerodynamic surface
21 , 22
. Yi and Ambopteryx preserve membranous tissue in situ around the styliform element
6
, which indicates a similar patagium-supporting role for this structure in this clade. Unfortunately, the preservation in Ambopteryx and Yi makes it impossible to reconstruct the configuration of the membranous tissue, which prevents further assessment of its exact function. Although previously a gliding function was ascribed to these structures in Yi 6 , other functions are also possible—for example, in display and ornamentation, or in contributing to wing-assisted incline running
23
. The hyper-elongate manual digit III of scansoriopterygids was previously interpreted as a feeding adaptation for extracting grubs during foraging, using a strategy similar to that of the extant aye-aye
15
. This interpretation is not supported in light of new data that indicate that the manual digits were surrounded by membranous tissues
6
, and in light of the limited mobility that we inferred from the morphology of the manual phalangeal joints. We suggest the primary function of the elongated digit III was the attachment of the wing membrane rather than feeding behaviour.

subSection.paragraph:
Systematic palaeontology of Scansoriopterygidae .
Phylogenetic definition. Scansoriopterygidae is the most inclusive clade that contains
Epidendrosaurus ningchengensis Zhang, Zhou and Xu 2002
, and
A. longibrachium
, but not
Dromaeosaurus albertensis Matthew and Brown 1992
,
Oviraptor philoceratops Osborn 1924
, and
Passer domesticus Linnaeus 1758
.

Diagnosis of the Scansoriopterygidae .
The Scansoriopterygidae differ from all other theropods on the basis of the following combination of characters:skull anteroposteriorly short and dorsoventrally deep; large external mandibular fenestra; scapula distally expanded; reduced deltopectoral crest of humerus; metacarpals I–III short; metacarpal III longer than II; and elongate manual digit III longer than other digits.
Differential diagnosis of Ambopteryx .
Ambopteryx is distinguishable from all other scansoriopterygids on the basis of the following combination of characters: styliform element shorter than humerus, opposite to the condition in Yi (this element is not preserved in
Epidexipteryx
and
Epidendrosaurus
); proximal margin of humerus more convex, and deltopectoral crest more elongate, than in Yi ; manual phalanx I-1 terminates level with the distal end of metacarpal II (this phalanx extends further distally in Yi and
Epidendrosaurus
); manual phalanx I-1 is much shorter than metacarpal II (length ratio is 0.62, compared to 0.91 in Yi and 0.9 in
Epidendrosaurus
); manual digit III is proportionally shorter than in Yi ; length ratio of manual phalanx III-1 to III-2 is greater than in Yi and
Epidendrosaurus
(1.29, 1.04 and 1.07 in Ambopteryx , Yi and
Epidendrosaurus
, respectively); and tibia is shorter than humerus (as in Yi ), which contrasts with the condition in
Epidendrosaurus
and
Epidexipteryx
.

Provenance of IVPP V24192 .
IVPP V24192 was collected from Jurassic strata exposed near Wubaiding Village in Reshuitang Subdistrict,Linyuan City, Liaoning Province. Before this specimen, the only known vertebrates collected from this locality were two salamanders
Pangerpeton sinensis
and
Chunerpeton tianyiensis
25 . A U–Pb date obtained using laser ablation inductively coupled mass spectrometry 26 from a lava breccia layer below the horizons that contain these salamander fossils produced a date of 164 ± 4 Ma.Strata cropping out near Wubaiding Village were previously considered to belong to the Tiaojishan Formation 26 . However, a few recent lithostratigraphic studies and biostratigraphic studies (mainly based on insects) have argued that the strata that are exposed in Wubaiding Village belong to the underlying Haifanggou Formation, and the main salamander-bearing sediments were deposited during the Callovian age 9 . The Tiaojishan Formation is mainly exposed in localities near Linglongta (Jianchang County, Liaoning Province), Nanshimen, Bawanggou and Fanzhangzi (Qinglong County, Hebei Province). An age of 161–160 Myr has previously been reported 27 for the fossiliferous vertebrate (for example,
Anchiornis
)-bearing horizons that are interbedded within the Tiaojishan Formation, as exposed in Linglongta Town. More recently, these fossil horizons in Linglongta Town have been further constrained to an interval that spans 160.89–160.25 Ma on the basis of high-precision U–Pb dating, which places this site in the late Oxfordian stage 28 . Although stratigraphic correlation between the Middle-to-Upper Jurassic strata in which the Yanliao Biota is distributed is still debated, growing evidence suggests that the Haifanggou Formation preserves the early phase of this biota (early Oxfordian), and the overlying Tiaojishan Formation records the later phase (Oxfordian) 9,29 ; these two phases are separated by approximately 2–3 million years. Unpublished results of secondary ionization mass spectrometry U–Pb dating using tuff samples from below the Ambopteryx - bearing bed produced an age of 163 Myr (H. He, personal communication), which indicates that this bed was deposited in the early Oxfordian stage of the Upper Jurassic.
IVPP V24192 was prepared by D. Li, a professional technician from the IVPP, under the supervision of the authors.

Bone histological analysis. Most of the limb elements were poorly preserved in IVPP V24192 ; among these limb elements, we could extract only one sample from the left humerus for bone histological analysis (Extended Data Fig. 1a ). We also took a sample from the unidentified fragment preserved near the gastroliths ( Fig. 1 ). The bone samples were embedded in one-component resin (EXAKT Technovit 7200) and hardened in a light polymerization device (EXAKT 520) for over 24 h. Thin cross-sections were cut using an accurate circular saw (EXAKT 300CP), and then were ground down using the EXAKT 400CS grinding system. The slides were ground to 40 µm—half the thickness that is typically necessary to visualize bone structure in similarly sized birds from the Jehol Biota—but the slides remained opaque.Images were taken using a digital camera (Zeiss AxioCam MRc5) under normal light (Zeiss AX10). Because of diagenetic alteration and breakage, the humeral cross-section provides little histological information; this information cannot be used to infer the ontogenetic stage of IVPP V24192 (Extended Data Fig. 2a, b ). Although also poorly preserved, the cross-section of the unidentified element shows that it is bone tissue (Extended Data Fig. 2c, d ).

Body mass estimate. Estimating the body mass of extinct animals is notoriously difficult, as it contains numerous unknown variables. The common practice used in palaeontology is based on empirical scaling relationships of limb bones (stylopodial length, circumference and so on) with body mass measurements obtained from living tetrapods 30–32 . As such, large differences occur between studies that use different empirical equations.Given the diverse limb proportions in extant and extinct tetrapods—for example, between terrestrial and arboreal forms—it is expected that using a single parameter from a single element across a large clade over million years of evolution is highly speculative. The scansoriopterygids Yi (STM31-2) 6 and
Epidexipteryx
(IVPP V15471 ) 14 were previously estimated to have a body mass of 380 g and 164 g, respectively,using the empirical equation in term of femoral length 31 . Using the same equation, the body mass of Ambopteryx (IVPP V24192 ) is 57 g—a surprisingly low value that is apparently far from realistic. Ambopteryx has a forelimb (combined length of humerus and ulna is 116.95 mm) that is intermediate in length between that of
Epidexipteryx
(IVPP V15471 , 92 mm) and Yi (STM31-2, 183.3 mm).Because the forelimb is longer than the hindlimb in all known scansoriopterygids, and because the forelimb probably has a major role in locomotion, it is impossible to accept such a low body mass estimate for Ambopteryx . The fact that the body mass estimate for Ambopteryx is erroneous indicates that femoral length is not a reliable parameter from which to infer body mass for non-avian paravians that approach the body shape of avians. Recent studies show that there is a correlation between stylopodial circumference and body mass 33 , and have been applied to estimate the body mass of non-avian dinosaurs 10,30 . Therefore—using an equation based on the circumference of the femur (log 10 (body mass) = 2.749 × log 10 (femoral circumference × 2 0.5 ) – 1.104) as previously described 10,30 —we alternatively estimated the body mass of Ambopteryx (IVPP V24192 ),
Epidexipteryx
(IVPP V15471 ), and Yi (STM31-2) to be 306 g, 391 g and 697 g, respectively. Our intention here is not to argue for one equation being more accurate than the other—although, in this instance, the equation based on femur circumference provides a more-realistic estimate. However, all estimates of body mass in extinct organisms should be treated with caution.

Scanning electron microscopy of soft tissues. Two samples from the feathers associated with the neck, and two samples from the potential traces of the membranous wings, in IVPP V24192 were taken for scanning electron microscopy analysis. These samples were mounted on stubs with carbon tape without gold coating.The samples were observed and photographed using a field emission scanning electron microscope equipped with a SE2 detector, at Key Laboratory of Unconventional Oil and Gas Geology, China Geology Survey.

Phylogenetic analysis. The phylogenetic position of Ambopteryx was analysed using a comprehensive data matrix that has recently become available for coelurosaurian phylogeny 6 , with the addition of IVPP V24192 and a stemward pygostylian Chongmingia zhengi (Supplementary Information).The dataset was analysed under equally weighted parsimony using the TNT v.1.5 software package 34 . The analysis was performed using the ‘New Technology search’ algorithm with sectorial search, ratchet, tree drift and tree fusion using the default settings in TNT, and the minimum tree length was found in ten replicates to recover as many tree islands as possible.We carried out a second round of branch-swapping using the traditional tree–bisection–reconnection method on the trees obtained in previous steps, to find the most-parsimonious trees. The branches of the most-parsimonious trees were collapsed if the minimal length was zero. Decay indices (Bremer support values) were calculated using the Bremer script embedded in TNT, and the absolute frequency of the bootstrap was calculated using 1,000 replicates using the default settings in TNT.

In total, 192 most-parsimonious trees were recovered with a length of 1,436 steps (consistency index = 0.315, retention index = 0.739). Ambopteryx was resolved within the Scansoriopterygidae and formed a sister to Yi in the strict consensus tree (Extended Data Fig. 7 ). This sister taxon relationship is supported by a single synapomorphy:the deltopectoral crest of humerus is very weakly developed and the proximal margin of humerus has rounded edges (character 140:2). Time-scaled Mesozoic coelurosaurian phylogeny. To estimate the divergence times of the major Mesozoic coelurosaurian clades, the strict consensus tree that we recovered was time-scaled. The temporal ranges of the fossil taxa were constrained using the first and last appearance datum of the geological stages or epochs in which each taxon was found 35 . When phylogenies that involve fossil taxa are time-calibrated, branches of zero length frequently occur 36,37 . These zerolength branches were smoothed using the ‘minimal branch length’ method used in recent studies 35,37 , which sets a minimum branch length (here, 1 million years). All these analyses were conducted using the timePaleoPhy function in the R package paleotree 38 .

Phylogenetic principal component analysis. To investigate the ecomorphospace disparity of Ambopteryx relative to other non-avian coelurosaurians and Mesozoic avians, we conducted a phylogenetic principal components analysis (PPCA) 39 . A dataset of the lengths of six appendicular elements (humerus, ulna, metacarpal II, femur, tibia and metatarsal III) from major groups of non-avian coelurosaurians and Mesozoic avians was assembled from direct measurements and the literature (Supplementary Table 3). Because the scaling relationships of the appendicular bones are poorly understood, we included only specimens that preserve complete lengths for all six bones, to avoid potential bias (see a previous publication 40 , and the references therein, for regression methods for estimating missing elements). The dataset comprises 57 taxa—including 35 non-avian coelurosaurians and 22 Mesozoic avians—and spans nearly the whole spectrum of the Mesozoic coelurosaurian phylogeny.

A composite super tree of the sampled coelurosaurians was created from the results of the present study combined with the results of recent phylogenetic studies 16,41 (Extended Data Fig. 8 ). Because the complete length of metacarpal II is unknown for
Epidexipteryx
, this taxon was removed from the tree. Polytomies were resolved randomly using the multi2di function in the R package ape 42 . The tree was time-calibrated using the ‘minimal branch length’ method on the basis of the absolute ages of the terminal taxa; this was carried out using the timePaleoPhy function in the R package paleotree 38 .

PPCA is a statistical method that not only performs a traditional principal component analysis (PCA) but also considers the phylogenetic non-independence between taxa when summarizing principal axes of variation 39,43 . All the measurements were log 10 -transformed to extract the non-allometric shape changes of the limb before performing the PPCA. The PPCA was performed using the phyl.pca function in the R package phytools 44 , which reconstructs the states of ancestral nodes using maximum likelihood under a Brownian model of evolution, with all branch lengths set to those obtained in previous time-calibrated phylogeny. To visualize the ecomorphospace, the principal component values of terminal taxa were projected on the phylogeny using the two-dimensional plotting function of phylomorphospace in the R package phytools 44 . The resulting phylomophospace displays both the magnitude and the direction of morphometric changes inferred along each branch.

The first three principal component values collectively account for over 98% of the variance, and could statically cover the whole ecomorphological diversity of sampled coelurosaurians (Supplementary Table 4). The first principal component axis (PC1) explained over 92% of the variance and negatively correlated with all measurements, which reflects the fact that it mainly represents size variation. Therefore, our analysis of ecomorphological diversity used only the scores of PC2 versus PC3. The eigenvector coefficients of PC2 are negatively correlated with the forelimb elements but positively correlated with hindlimb elements, which indicates that PC2 represents the relative elongation of the forelimb compared to the hindlimb. PC3 contains eigenvector coefficients that are negatively correlated with metacarpal II, the femur and the tibia, but positively correlated with other elements. The opposite signs of the eigenvector coefficients of PC3 describe the shortening of the metacarpal II or the femur relative to the ulna or metatarsal III. Among coelurosaurians, Ambopteryx and Yi have metacarpals that are unusually short, as depicted by the large gap between the Scansoriopterygidae and other coelurosaurian clades along PC3.
Epidendrosaurus
was recovered in a position relatively distant from that of Yi and Ambopteryx , which strongly suggests that—in scansoriopterygids—limb proportion is heavily affected by ontogeny.

A separate PPCA was performed using only the forelimb measurements (Supplementary Table 5). The first two principal component values account for over 99% of the variance; therefore, a binary plot of these two axes was used. PC1 negatively correlates with all measurements, and thus mainly accounts for size variation. PC2 explains over 26% of the variance, and contains eigenvector coefficients that positively correlate with metacarpal II but negatively correlate with the humerus and ulna. The relatively high loading of metacarpal II indicates that PC2 mainly represents the elongation of this element relative to the humerus and ulna. Taken together, the binary plot of PC1 and PC2 generally describes whether the increase of the forelimb largely results from the elongation of the proximal (humerus and ulna) or the distal (metacarpal) forelimb elements. Scansoriopterygids deviate from other coelurosaurians in the morphospace formed by PC1 and PC2, and are plotted on the bottom right corner of the morphospace; this reveals that the elongation of their forelimb largely derives from the elongation of the humerus and ulna. The morphospace occupied by Mesozoic avians, dromaeosaurids and troodontids largely overlapped with one another (as well as with that of oviraptorosaurs and some more basal coelurosaurians); all of these clades centre on the top of the morphospace, along PC2. This distribution indicates that the elongation of the forelimb in non-scansoriopterygid pennaraptorans (including birds) is largely driven by the elongation of the metacarpals.
